stem: Based on the patient information, indicate the appropriate routine screening recommendation for each patient.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:00 SBAR for routine screening recommendations.

Situation: Reviewing patient charts for appropriate routine cancer and health screenings.

Background: Patient A (John Smith, 68yo male, smoker, BMI 31). Patient B (Jane Doe, 52yo female, postmenopausal, family history of breast cancer). Patient C (Maria Rodriguez, 28yo female, sexually active, no significant medical history). Patient D (Robert Jones, 45yo male, sedentary lifestyle, elevated cholesterol).

Assessment: Patient A requires lung cancer screening due to age and smoking history. Patient B needs a mammogram due to age and family history. Patient C needs a Pap smear per guidelines. Patient D requires a colonoscopy due to age and elevated cholesterol.

Recommendation: Please verify and schedule the appropriate screenings as outlined above. Contact provider with any questions. Ensure patient education is provided before each screening. Verify insurance coverage prior to scheduling. Schedule follow-up appointments as necessary. Document all actions in the EHR.

07:15 Provider confirmed screening recommendations. Scheduling initiated.

clinicalPearls: Routine screenings are essential for early detection and prevention of diseases.
Screening guidelines vary based on age, sex, risk factors, and medical history.
Patient education and shared decision-making are crucial components of screening recommendations.

questionTrap.trap: Students may misinterpret patient history or risk factors, leading to incorrect screening recommendations.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully review the EHR data, especially the patient's age, sex, relevant medical history, and risk factors, to determine the appropriate screening tests based on current guidelines.
